week3.practice1_html:
What it is

â€œWin Your Day with Breakfastâ€ is about beginning each morning with a protein-rich, anti-inflammatory meal that steadies your energy, mood, and hormones so your scalp gets the nourishment it needs for new growth.

Solveig, youâ€™re in the regrowth start phaseâ€”your shedding has calmed, and those baby hairs are proof your follicles are waking up. This is where stabilization deepens into visible resilience.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Set your morning anchor: Aim to eat within 60â€¯minutes of waking to ground your hormones for the day.
  2. Build your 30g protein plate: Mix any combo such as eggs or Greek yogurt with berries and oats, or a vegan smoothie with plant protein, chia, and spinach.
  3. Add calm fuel: Include one antiâ€‘inflammatory colorâ€”like blueberries, turmeric, or leafy greensâ€”to ease invisible stress from inside out.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Feel steadier energy midâ€‘morning, fewer cravings or crashes, and smoother focus. Over weeks, scalp itch or tenderness may ease.

week3.practice3_html:
What it is

Time Your Food helps you create a gentle gap between your last meal and bedtime, so your body can digest fully and ease into deep, restorative sleep.

Why this practice matters for you now

Solveig, youâ€™re in the regrowth start phaseâ€”shedding has calmed and those new baby hairs show your bodyâ€™s ready to rebuild. But evening eating just before bed can keep your stress hormones slightly elevated overnight, slowing that repair work. Since ongoing stress has been your main driver, this practice is your â€œbig dominoâ€: it steadies blood sugar and lets nighttime recovery kick in more efficiently to strengthen new growth.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Pick a consistent dinner time that ends at least two hours before bedâ€”start with 8â€¯p.m. if you sleep around 10â€¯p.m.
  2. If you get hungry later, choose a light, proteinâ€‘friendly snack (like a handful of nuts or yogurt) instead of a heavy meal.
  3. Keep caffeine cut-off by early afternoon (youâ€™re already doing well around 12â€“3â€¯p.m.) and replace late-night nibbling with a calming ritualâ€”herbal tea, light stretch, or reading.
  4. Note how you feel in the morning: lighter, less bloated, more rested. Those are signs your bodyâ€™s using the night for repair rather than digestion.

What to look for
